awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Criminal Records and Housing Discrimination: An Audit Study
awd_abstract_narration:
The proportion of the U.S. population with a criminal record has dramatically increased during the past four decades, and research has documented the ways in which a criminal record creates and reinforces inequalities in employment, health, and other outcomes.  However, less is known about how a criminal record affects access to housing. This project will identify the prevalence and scope of criminal record use to disqualify applicants at an early stage of the housing application process. It will also detect whether there are racial disparities in the consideration of criminal histories by landlords. It examines if neighborhood disadvantage conditions the stigmatizing effect of a criminal record. Finally, it advances understanding of how landlords weigh criminal background checks and how they implement recent changes in the laws that require use of criminal histories in these transactions.  Project findings will provide greater understanding of how U.S. housing policy is working, particularly for those with criminal backgrounds.

This project consists of a field experiment and qualitative interviews. An email-based audit study of rental housing units will involve contacting landlords and inquiring to see the rental properties. These emails will signal race and the criminal history status of the potential applicants. The audit study will be paired with interviews with landlords about how they use criminal histories in the application process, and their understanding of recent policy changes regarding criminal record use in such evaluations.  This research will contribute to a growing body of findings on the durable effects of criminal justice contact, as well as socio-legal research on how property managers adapt to and comply with policy changes. It also contributes to sociological theories focused on discrimination, racial inequality and urban residence.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Comprehending the struggle to find and maintain housing is vital to understanding cycles of inequality and poverty in urban neighborhoods. The research project utilized an experimental correspondence study design, in which pairs of online messages were sent to a random sample of housing providers in Ohio, inquiring whether a particular rental unit was still available. Half of the messages included a disclosure that the prospective tenant had a criminal record, to gauge whether and how landlords screen renters who disclose a record. Messages were signed with names most common to Black, White, and Hispanic men and women to evaluate whether the effect of stigma varied according to the race of the prospective tenant. Then, we recorded and coded landlord responses to evaluate the effect of criminal history, race, and gender on the likelihood of receiving a positive response from the housing provider. The findings of this study advance knowledge in multiple sociological subfields.

First, this study contributed to the sociology of punishment and sociological knowledge of the enduring effects of a criminal record by examining broad exclusionary policies in housing. There was a strong and statistically significant effect of disclosing a criminal record on the likelihood of receiving a response from a landlord, which largely took the form of nonresponse. Many landlords would respond positively to a message send without disclosing a criminal record, and simply not respond to the message that disclosed the criminal record.

Second, the research contributed to the knowledge of race in that the audit study examined racial disparities in the stigma of a criminal record. Criminal records were used to a similar extent across all race and gender pairing, though Black and Hispanic men received the fewest positive responses overall.  Thus, the use of criminal records in screening results in a disparate impact on racial and ethnic minorities because of the overrepresentation of Black and Hispanic populations in the criminal justice system and persistent racial discrimination that leaves Black and Hispanic renters with fewer housing opportunities, to begin with.

Third, contributing to the field of urban sociology, the findings of this project demonstrate the variation in screening practices across neighborhoods. Criminal records were a particularly useful screening tool in gentrifying neighborhoods. This result suggests that landlord screening practices may play a key role in the production of urban inequality and neighborhood change.

In addition to these intellectual pursuits, this project also was conducted with the assistance of undergraduate research assistants and was an opportunity for these students to learn about social science research in practice. This was not only a pedagogical opportunity to teach students about social science research methods and data collection, but also provided students with skills and training in preparation for both continued higher education and future employment. 

This study also has broad and timely implications for public policy. The United States is in the midst of an affordable housing crisis, and the population living with a criminal record is massive. In 2016, the Department of Housing and Urban Development issued guidelines for the use of criminal background checks in housing, which had previously been unregulated. The knowledge produced by this study provides evidence of the disparate impact of criminal records screening on Black and Hispanic renters. It is imperative to fully understand the barriers to successful reentry and housing security in order to develop more effective policies to address these pressing issues.
